Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO)-A Change Detection Array in the Pacific Arctic Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Arctic is changing. The Distributed Biological Observatory studies these changes in the northern Bering and Chukchi seas. Investigators sample locations that are biologically important in U.S. territorial waters. These locations have been sampled annually since 2010. Other investigators also sample the same locations. As a result, the locations are sampled multiple times a year. Data are collected on environmental conditions including water column and sea floor animals that are food for whales, seals, and birds. Data are shared internationally. The project contributes to the U.S. National Ocean Policy and Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee 5-year plan. The data will be of value to U.S. and international science and management agencies, private industry, and local communities as they try to understand changes to the environment. The project supports three graduate students.

The observational plan includes standard hydrographic and biological measurements along five transect lines located in the northern Bering and Chukchi Seas. These sampling locations are arrayed south-to-north and reflect a gradient of seasonal sea ice change and seawater warming. The investigators chose these 5 regions because they are zones of high biological productivity and biodiversity. Results so far indicate a freshening and warming of Pacific seawater which transits northward over the spring to fall season. These changes have impacted prey for larger marine mammals and seabirds. Satellite observations are also used to evaluate seasonal changes in sea ice concentration, surface seawater temperature, and chlorophyll concentration. The biological measurements focus on lower trophic levels and shipboard surveys of upper trophic level organisms. This research will increase our understanding of the impact of key environmental forcing parameters on biological change in the system. The collection of key prey-predator biological data along with physical and chemical measurements will allow for analyses and ecosystem modeling which will promote better understanding of Arctic environmental changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ecosystem of the Pacific sector of the Arctic Ocean is changing
rapidly due to the warming climate. In order to document these
changes, understand why they are happening, and predict future
scenarios, it is necessary to collect interdisciplinary measurements on a regular
basis. The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO) was originated in
2010 by a group of international investigators in order to obtain
timeseries of critical ecosystem parameters in the Bering, Chukchi,
and Beaufort Seas. The concept behind the DBO program is that numerous
international vessels progress through the area each year conducting
their individual research programs, which provides the opportunity
to collect measurements at a common set of key sites during their transits. A
total of 8 DBO sections have been identified, corresponding to regions
of enhanced biological activity, or "hotspots". These sections cover a
large latitudinal gradient from the northern Bering Sea to the eastern
Beaufort Sea. The idea is that ships can stop and carry out
measurements at any or all of the sites, and, by doing so, build a
timeseries of observations over the years for the community to
share. The sampling at each site can include physical, chemical, and
biological measurements of the water column; benthic sampling; and
observations of marine mammals and seabirds.

To date, the DBO program has been a huge success, resulting in a
coordinated set of interdisciplinary observations. However, to have
maximal impact, the data need to be assembled, quality controlled,
documented, and made available to the community via data
repositories. The goal of our project was to carry out these steps for
the physical oceanographic data collected from 2010-2017 along
DBO sections 1-6. In order to carry this out, we needed to track all major
shipboard field campaigns spanning this period, and maintain
consistent contact with principle investigators (PIs) from multiple
institutions and countries. The datasets from this search were
meticulously organized so as to maintain connection with the
original projects, PIs, and complementary datasets.

Over the course of the project our group submitted a total of 49
datasets to the Arctic Data Center repository, corresponding to
physical oceanographic observations recorded within the DBO
regions. These submissions were curated such that each contain only
high quality hydrographic sections including ocean temperature,
salinity, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, fluorescence, and at times
additional parameters. The data collected were sourced from a diverse
array of ships, PIs, countries, and funding sources, and would not
have otherwise been published for public access or long term archival.
This provides critical information to the community to be used in
ongoing and future interdisciplinary studies of the Pacific Arctic
system.

The project also funded a graduate student to carry out an
investigation of the year-long mean and seasonally-varying circulation
of the Chukchi Sea shelf.  This was done using data from 20 moorings
that were deployed from 2013-14 by different research groups. Each of
the groups had their own regional objectives, but we took a system
approach and combined all of the data together to investigate
shelf-wide processes. We determined that temperature signals propagate
northward from Bering Strait along the major flow pathways, consistent
with the calculated flow speeds. However, the salinity signals do not
follow this pattern, but instead are influenced by local polynya
activity across the shelf. When polynyas are formed in winter, the
open water quickly freezes and rejects salt into the surface layer. As
a result, the surface water becomes more dense than the underlying
water and mixes the salt downward into the water column. It was also
revealed that the flow throughout the Chukchi Sea is stronger during
the summer months (May-August) and weaker during the winter months
(December-March), although wind forcing has a large affect on the
direction and magnitude of the flow.  These results will help the
community more accurately determine the seasonal evolution of
nutrients on the shelf, which is invaluable for understanding the
presence of the biological hotspots at the DBO sites.
